summary: This is a motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team for a new trial, arguing that Juror No. 50 (Scotty David) committed misconduct by falsely denying on his jury questionnaire and during voir dire that he had been a victim of sexual abuse. The motion contends that the juror's subsequent media interviews revealed he used his personal experience to influence other jurors, depriving Maxwell of her right to an impartial jury. The document also references a second, unidentified juror who similarly failed to disclose being a victim of sexual assault.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, convicted of sex trafficking and related charges. Her defense team is filing this motion for a new trial based on alleged juror misconduct.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the motion for a new trial.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the motion for a new trial.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the motion for a new trial.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the motion for a new trial.

persons.name: Scotty David
persons.context: A juror in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial who, after the verdict, gave media interviews revealing he was a victim of childhood sexual abuse and that he shared this with other jurors during deliberations to persuade them about victim credibility.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: A defense expert witness on memory who testified, challenging the reliability of the accusers' memories. The motion states Juror No. 50 dismissed her testimony based on his personal experience.

persons.name: Lucia Osborne-Crowley
persons.context: A reporter for The Independent who conducted the first interview with Juror No. 50 after the trial.

persons.name: Annie Farmer
persons.context: Referenced in the motion as an alleged victim/witness in the Maxwell case. Juror No. 50 communicated with her on social media after the trial.

persons.name: Luc Cohen
persons.context: A Reuters journalist who interviewed Juror No. 50.

connections.description: Pagliuca is one of the lead defense attorneys representing Maxwell in her motion for a new trial.
Scotty David was a juror who convicted Maxwell. The motion argues his undisclosed bias as a victim of sexual abuse prejudiced the trial against her.
Juror No. 50 communicated with Annie Farmer on Twitter after the trial, thanking her for her bravery and stating her story was critical to the verdict.
Juror No. 50 gave an interview to journalist Lucia Osborne-Crowley and interacted with her on social media regarding the published article.
Dr. Loftus was an expert witness called by the defense to testify about the reliability of memory.
The motion states Juror No. 50 refused to credit Dr. Loftus's expert testimony on memory based on his personal experience as a victim.

events.title: Juror No. 50's First Media Interview
events.description: Juror Scotty David gives an interview to Lucia Osborne-Crowley of The Independent, revealing he was a victim of sexual abuse, shared this with the jury, and that it influenced deliberations.

events.title: Additional Juror Interviews
events.description: Juror No. 50 gives interviews to the Daily Mail and Reuters, providing further details about his influence on jury deliberations and revealing a second juror also disclosed being a victim of sexual abuse.

events.title: Juror No. 50's Voir Dire
events.description: The brief oral examination of Juror No. 50 during jury selection, during which he denied any bias or inability to be fair and impartial.

events.title: Filing of Motion for New Trial
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this motion for a new trial based on juror misconduct by Juror No. 50 and an unidentified second juror.

events.title: Pre-trial Hearing on Voir Dire
events.description: A hearing where the court declined to permit attorney-conducted voir dire but expressed confidence it could 'smoke out' dishonest jurors.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Juror No. 50 (Scotty David) admitted in post-trial media interviews that he was a victim of childhood sexual abuse, which he did not disclose on his jury questionnaire or during voir dire.

Juror No. 50 stated he shared his personal abuse experience with other jurors during deliberations to help them understand the accusers' credibility and memory, directly contradicting defense expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus's testimony.
A second, unidentified juror also reportedly disclosed during deliberations that they were a victim of sexual abuse, and also did not disclose this during jury selection.

The defense motion argues that truthful answers from Juror No. 50 would have provided a valid basis to challenge him for cause, thereby depriving Maxwell of her Sixth Amendment right to an impartial jury.
The motion requests a new trial or, alternatively, an evidentiary hearing with subpoenas for Juror No. 50's communications and social media records.
